GREECE - TURKEY LINE.
Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.
PALESTINE - SYRIA LINE.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).
RED SEA LINE.

Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for JEDDAH, SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, and ADEN ; and in the intervening weeks for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct. Calls will be made at TOR (for Mount Sinai) as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company's Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

div.head: The Egyptian Gazette THE ENGLISH DAILY NEWSPAPER. ' ESTABLISHED 1880. Editor and Manager - R. SHERLING. Price: ONE PIASTRE TARIFF.
FRIDAY, MAY 17, 1907.
THE SULTAN AND THE ARABS.
div.p: It has been announced lately, writes a Correspondent of "Globe," that the Sultan has appointed a Commission, composed of disting uished generals and ulemas, and has directed them to proeeod to the Yemen, to discuss witli the rebel Arab tribes the nature of their grievances, and to arrange terms of settlement. Although it is rather late in the ilay to take this step, it is to he hoped that the negotiations may suceoed. The civil

war which has so long raged in the Yemen has been disastrous in its effects, not only upon the population, but also upon the prestige of the Sultan. For more thart three years the Arab tribes have paid no taxes, nor have they provided the customary recruits to the Army. They have been in open rebellion; they have repeatedly defeated the Turkish troops with heavy losses; they have captured important fortresses like Sanaa, with large stores of arms, artillery, and ammunition. Whole regiments tf the Sultan's troops have deserted Itodily to the enemy. I/ast year when the Arab forces surrounded Sanaa, the Turkish Governor surrendered ; the garrison marched out as prisoners of war, the officers were shot, and such of the rank and file as did not join the Arabs were escorted to Hodeida and shipped back to Akabeh. The reconquest of the Yemen wus, indeed, a hopeless task, and Abdul Hamid has done wisely in abandoning the effort. If the Sultan's Commission can satisfy the demands of the rebellious tribes by offeringthem autonomy, such as was granted years ago to the Lebanon, ami a similar amount of Home Rule which will free the Arabs from the oppressive taxation of the Turkish Valis, the Moslem world will rejoice, and its ruler will gain strength and prestige. Upon our side also there will be cause for rejoicing if a peaceful settlement can he effected, for it will free Aden, Egypt, the Sudan, and the Indian Empire from a cons-_ taut cause of anxiety and religious restlessness among our Moslem subjects. It is probable that the high-handed proceedings of the German Ambassador in Constantinople, in demanding the exile of Fehim Pasha, the foster-brother of the Sultan himself, has opened the eyes of the latter to the grave danger which threatens his Empire through German aggression. Notable evidence of a change in Abdul Hamid's feelings towards Germany has been shown recently by the growing favour which he has exhibited to British enterprise in his dominions. The construction of the-quay*. docks, and workhouses in Constantinople, which had been so long delayed, notwithstanding their necessity, has now been entrusted to an Anglo-French syndicate, in the face of strenuous opposition by the German Ambassador. An English engineer, Sir William Willcocks, has been entrusted with the survey of the works for restoring the ancient canals and irrigation works along the Tigris, and an Irade has been issued by the Sultan, ordering their completion. It is to be hoped that the carrying out of these important works will also be entrusted to British capitalists and engineers, who have already proved their efficiency by the remarkable public works which they have carried out in India and Egypt, with such notable success. The effects of irrigation upon the fertile lands between the Tigris and the Euphrates will be to render Mesopotamia as rich as Egypt, with important advantages to the finances of the Ottoman Empire, as well as to increase of commercial activity in those regions, by which India and Great Britain will benefit. It is too much to hope that as a result of the friendly feelings of the Sultan, lie may be induced to entrust to British enterprise the completion of a line of railway to connect Koweit on the Persian Gulf with Bagdad, placing it under international control ? German trade would not suffer by the completion of the Bagdad Railway in tlie.se circumstances. On the contrary, the commerce which British enterprise in the Persian Gulf would bring to the railway; would soon make any payment by the Sultan, on account of the kilometric guarantee which is so stubbornly insisted upon by the Berlin financiers altogether unnecessary. But the successful completion of the public works in Mesopotamia, and of the Bagdad Railway, depends chiefly upon the power of t he Sultan to protect the engineers and the workmen constructing them. And it is only by consent of the Arab tribes, who liave been so victorious hitherto, that their safety can be assured. For this reason the visit of the Sultan's Commission, now on its way to the Yemen, is so important at the present juncture. Its task will be a difficult one, for the tribes believe that their recent successes in the field are a guarantee of future ones. It is an illusion,.for it is well known that the Sultail could easily obtain the aid of the Kaiser if hq asked it, in subduing the whole of Arabia and establishing his rule more effectively than he has been able to do hitherto. It is true that the price which would he asked for such assistance would be onerous, and such as he would not willingly pay, hut desperate cases require desperate remedies sometimes. British Ministers have now a chance of gaining the goodwill of the Sultan by offering their services as mediators between him and his rebellious subjects, which may never occur again, and it is to be hoped thut Sir Edward Grey,| either through the Indian Government or directly, will feel able to seize it. It is probable that the inde)>endent chiefs, having now formed on Arabian Federation, and elected their own Caliph, will not easily believe in the genuineness of the promises which will he made to them by the Sultan's Commissioners, and will be unwilling to surrender the results of their victories. In that case, no other Power could claim to command so much confidence as Great Britain. There is little doubt as to what Lord Beaeonsfield, if he were still alive, woidd do in the circumstances.

div.head: Education In the Fayoum.
div.p: Fayoum Correspondant comments upon the great interest taken in the Fayoum Government school by the Mudir, and refers e-pecially to the progress made hy tho pupils in learning English. Both the Mudir and the lead master of the school received their education in England and have done much towards the advancement of the study of English in the Fayoum. In future the pupils of the Fayoum schoql will be examined at the school and not bo required to present themselves at Cairo for examination.

div.head: he Fayoum Sports.
div.p: The Fayoum Government school sports, the results of which were given in a recont issue, were attended by an exceptionally large crowd. Tho Mudir was an interested spectator, as were also Mr. and Mrs Reed, Mr. Martino, "'asset Bey, Mr and Mrs. Simpson, Mr. and Mrs. Mayne, Mr. and Mrs. Arbib, Mr. Andrus, Mr. Rankin etc. Everything went off very well and the afternoon was most enjoyable. The vnrious events were well contested and considerable progress wait shown by the boys, who take a very keen interest in the sports. The prizes were distributed by the Mudir.

div.head:
LORD CROMER
MR. EDWARD DICEY'S OPINION.
div.p: Writing in the "Empire Review," Mr. Edward Dicey remarks :—

"I had for long past been of opinion that it would he for tho advantage both of England and Egyfyt if his lordship were replaced by a younger man, less autocratic in character,more sympathetic in disjiosition, and more ready to recognise the fundamental differences between the West and the Easb, and as I lutve already expressed these opinions in print, I cannot deny that the retirement of Lord Cromer and his replacement by a younger man will, in my judgment, by a gain to Egypt and possibly to to England.

"First. 1 hold that though the material prosperity of Egypt has been greatly increased under the reign of economy and order which Lord Cromer has introduced, this prosperity has not earned, und could not reasonably be expected ,to earn, the gratitude of the native Egyptians. ,

"Secondly. I hold that during the quarter of a century throughout which Egypt has been ruled under an absolute, though benevolent, autocracy, Egypt' has become less fitted for self-government or any kind of autonomy than she was at the commencement of our military occupation.
"Thirdly. I contend that the latent dislike entertained by all Mohammedan races for Christian supremacy constitutes a permanent cause of unrest.

"Fourthly. I consider that the attempt to administer the affairs of Egypt hy English officials and thus excluding the natives from any important share in the internal administration of Egypt*!ms proved a failure.

"And lastly 1 am convinced that so long as England declines to regularise her position by declaring her Protectorate over Egypt, it; is u blunder on onijppnrt not to avail ourselves of the co-operation of the Khedive hy utilising his personal influence as the legal sovereign of Egypt, and to wilfully disregard his not unreasonable susceptibilities."
THE GOVERNMENT CRITICISED.
In uu open letter to Lord Cromer in a London contemporary there is tho following passage

.We all know, of course, that reasons of lMfftfh are alleged, but to most people the Government seemed to be a little too insistent on tlie point. Qui s'e.rcuse s'accitf. Tweedledum and Twegdledee have been making tlicia customary inquiries and asking their usual pertinent questions and are able to say that there is more in the ease than meets the eye. After all, can any man he blamed for losing confidence in a Government 'which is led hy a Campbell-Bannerman and largely influenced hy the changeling Winston Churchill 1 We say freely that we believe you had the full .and .faithful support of Sir Edward Grey, one of the very, very few capable men that the Ministry possesses, even as you lmd the implicit confidence of such great Foreign Secretaries before him as I/ord Salisbury, Lord Lunsdowne, and Ixird Rosebery. But what C.-B. thought of you wc can easily guess. You were too strong a man to suit them, and wc nVe not in the least surprised to learn that your opinions clashed. Liberal Governments have certainly been unfortunate in Egypt/ They have lost you, and they lost Gordon ! We can only hope that,-after a period of repose and recreation, you will see your way to return to public life. We cannot believe that so energetic a worker contemplates absolute—VOtirement, and, after all, you are hy fitmnSns^an old man yet.
. SIR'ELDON jORST-

A number of rumours have been bruited 'about as to the exact fcliaracter of the otlicial speeches at yesterday's ceremony at Ras el-Tin Palace'These reports appear to have originated Owing*to the fact that the local newspapers were unable to obtain the text of the Khedive's and -Sir Eldon's speeches from the official sources to which application vjtfs Inode. Consequently the quidnuncs drew elaborate conclusions from the noii-piimication of the^Speeches and it was rumoured that important political reasons rendered publication unwise. We are authorised to slate that all such rumours are entirely destitute of any foundation and the speeches were of n simple official character in no way differing from the usual type of speeches delivered on these occasions.
Sir Eldon Gorst on returning from Ras el-Tin Palace yesterday lunched at the British Consulate with Mr. and Mrs. Gould.1 The other guests included Mr. Ronald Graham, Colonel Chapman,and Mr. Gaisford.

In the afterno n Sir Eldon again proceeded to Ras el-Tin Palace and hail an audience with the Khedive. Sir Eldon afterwards returned to the Savoy Palace Hotel and left with his suite for Cairo by the evening express.

div.head:
THE FINANCIAL CRISIS
EXCESSIVE SPECULATION. FOUNDERS' SHARES IMPUGNED-
div.p: The Bulletin of the British Chamber of Commerce of Egypt in its May issue contains the following article :—

For some time past warnings have been given by prudent and experienced people against the excessive speculation which has been going on in local stocks and shares and in building land. No heed was given to these warnings by many people who had the means of checking this excessive speculation. The Egyptian banks did their beat to moderate the gambling fever by refusing to increase their advances on local shares, whilst several of them went further and confined their advances to the better class of securities, entirely eliminating those of a financial or land speculating character. The bettor class stockbrobers also, discouraged speculation by refusing to execute purchases which would have had to be carried over. The hanks and respectable brokers at tho time came in for the usual invective from the disappointed gambler, and from the enter- prisingbrokeror promoter desirous of unloading his wares on an unsuspecting public. The fresh wave of prosperity, engendered by a record- breaking, bumper cotton crop, marketed at prices hitherto unhoped for, proved, however, in spite of the conservative action of the hanks and others, to he such an incentive
to.................. shall we say enterprise 7 that

scarcely a day passed without the shares of one or more new companies being offered for public subscription. The promoters of these ventures secured the favour of the Bourse frequenting fraternity, and the subsequent necessary official quotation, by a judicious distribution of founders' shares (which vicious feature in public companies is one which finds much favour with the Levantineapeculator). (l) These founders' shares of the nominal value of 1 /- each were quickly rigged up to (in some cases) £4 or £0 apiece, and the happy allottees at jiar, having realised a handsome profit with no initial risk, could not do loss than bid up the ordinary shares to a premium, almost before the prospectus was out of the printer's hands. Without going so far a^ to say that ntPconipany could get its shares quoted officially, without in some way subsidising the leading brokers, it is quite true that those who did not do so had to wait a long time for a quotation. A premium being thus established, the whole of the capital was inevitably over subscribed. This phenomenon was many times repeated, and a remarkuble feature was that the premium remained some considerable time after allotment.

The first successful promoters naturally found many imitators. Business on the Bourse was brisk. One heard of colossal sums gained in brokerages alone. Consequently, side by side with the creation of new companies, recruits came thick and fast to the Bourse ; hank clerks 'left their employment to start as brokers, with the aid of borrowed capital ; oilier brokers turned their concerns into companies (needless to say the shares were immediately quoted at a premium), and people without the means of paying differences, let alone taking up their purchases with their own money, were induced to speculate and were promised unlimited accommodation. Naturally this could not go on for ever. Carrying over rates at from 20 to 80 per cent, and even more in some cases, could not he eternally borne, and nil at once business came to a full stop, owing to many people being unable to carry their load any longer, and prices fell 25 or more per cent. It is perhaps as well that the pace was made so fast : it was merry while it lasted, hut fortunately the check has come at a time when the market is well able to support losses. It is indeed remarkable that there have been hitherto so comparatively few failures.

The methods of the brokers' committee in practically declaring a moratorium (2) are doubtless open to much criticism, and we doubt whether they will be sufficiently appreciated in? Europe by bankers and others who have lent money on Egyptian shares. This much is, however, to he said for them, that they have given a certain amount of breathing time, mid have enabled the monthly settlement for the end of April to lie carried through quietly. There were two or three failures earlier in the month (.3) and one small failure recently, while nnotfibr firm has had to lie helped over. At the time of wilting, the feeling is distinctly better, and we have heard of several enquiries for shares at good prices. Many shares, are in our opinion, still too high to attract the bona fide investor, while on the other hand, many of the more speculative varieties are worthy of attention., from people who have the means and the inclination to go in for such.

We do not wish it to be understood that all local stockbrokers, or even promoters, are mi; scrupulous. We are thankful to say that there are many honourable exceptions; and we deliberately record our conviction that the country at bottom is sound, and that there is no ground for anxiety as to the ultimate results of the majority of Egyptian Companies.

(1) Tho Egyptian Government wan so impressed by tlie evils of the founders' sharo system that it has recently placed considerable obstacles in tho way of forming Egyptian SoottUe Anonytnes having founders' shares. This explains the favour which the English limited liability regime now finds in the. .eyea of promoters. „ - (2) So called "making up prioes'' were established, below whioli.it was forbidden to deal, the idea being to stop a panic whiob might have been bronght about by "bear" raids in aa unsupported market. (3) In tlie oaso of one of theso, a broker bad bought a large number of shares in a financial concern for account of clerks in that concern !Comment ia superfluous.

The Government has Beriously taken in handthe question of the regulation of the Bourses, find everything points to a speedy settlement of that question on sound and practical lines. Wtyn this is carried out, the abuses and irregularities to which we have referred will automatically disappear. And with the. disappearance of abuses the Egyptian share market will, we confidently anticipate, regain ita freedom and elasticity. ( LONDON OPINION. An article on the same subject in the "Pall Mall Gazette" concludes as follows :— It is reckless over-speculation that has conduced to the present state of affairs, in addition to which share.4 in newly-floated companies, which had no tangible assets and whose business prospects were highly hypothetical, often stood unjustifiably at a substantial premium a few days after issue.

div.head: THE KHEDIVE-
div.p: The Khedive utteended the midday prayers to-day at the new mosque built hy Hassan Bey Abdallah- in Korn el Shoukafa street.

div.head: THE BRITISH AGENCY
div.p: The British Agency's summer quarters nt Alexandria will be located in the residence of Mr. Percy Carver at Bulkeley.

div.head: NEW CAIRO SUBURB
div.p: The African Mission have accepted an offer generously made by Maitre Gaston Privat, of a site of nearly one feddan, free of cost, for the erection of new day schools and church at Esbet-el-Nakhl, the penultimate station on the Matarieh line. The property, which consists of about 40 feddans, was purchased last year by Maitre Privat, ami has been laid nut in plots for building purposes, ami macadamised roads, bordered .with eucalyptus trees, have already been made. Several villas are being constructed and there is no doubt that the spot will in time become a favorite residential suburb since it is rumoured that the State Railway Board have decided upon electrifying the line from Cairo to Marg.

div.head: CATTLE PLAGUE.
div.p: Up to the close of the week ending 13th May, 144 fatal cases of cattle plague were reported in Egypt Of these, 24 cases occurred in the Beba district, 49 in Maglmgho, 22 in Beni-Mazar, 22 in Aboil Kerkes, 10 in Minieh, 3 in Fashn, 7 Melluwi and 1 at Dei rout. Even though tlie complaint is confined to a few restricted areas 'it is none the leas a matter for uneasiness, both to the farmers and the Public Health Department, and no effort is being spared by the latter to obtain a clean bill of health for Egypt. Judging by the information that the Serum Institute, which the Public Health Department established some three years ago at Abassieh, is about to lie re-opened, it might be assumed that the cattle plague is really on tho increase, unless the object of reopening the Institute is for the supply of serum to the Sudan. It is a well-known fact that when the Serum Institute was closed some eighteen months ago there was an enormous reserve of serum and a great portion of this was sent to the Sudan : the lengthy transit, however, had a deteriorating effect on the serum and there were statements made that it was not so efficacious in the south as the north. It has been well proved in Egypt itself and has contributed greatly to the suppression and localising of cattle plague.

div.head: NEW CAIRO HAMMAM.
div.p: We mentioned a short time ago that one of tho old landmarks of the Capital was about to disappear by the closing of tho Hainmain in the Square Halim. Tho lease had several more years to run but the proprietors, Messrs. For- nario and Rossi, accepted an indemnity to cede the premises os the site was required for a variety theatre and music hall. We now learn that the former lessees have entered into negotiations with a powerful local syndicate of financiers, with whom is associated the Socidtl Belge-Egyptienne de 1'Esbekieh, for tlie erection of a new establishment in a central position, most probably on a plot of land at the back of Shepheard's Hotel belonging to the above company. It isiipped to begin building operations in the course of tho summer.

div.head: OBITUARY-
div.p: The deatli is announced at Now York of Major General Henty Ronald Dougins Me Ivor, who was formerly Inspector of Cavalry in Egypt in the time of Ismail Pasha. He died at the age of sixty five and during his adventurous career lmd fought under eighteen flags. He served as uu Ensign in India in the Sepoy Mutiny, as a Lieutenant in Italy under Garibaldi, as a Captain in Spain under Don Carlos, as a Major in the Confederate Army on tlie Staff's of Geuends Stonewall Jackson and J. E. B. Stuart, as a Lieutenunt-Colonel under the Emperor Maximilian in Mexico, as a Colonel under Napoleon III. in the Franco- Prussian War, and as a Major-General under King Milan of Servia. He had also served in the ten years' war in Cuba, in Brazil, in Argentina, in Crete, in Greeco, and in tlie two C'urlist revolutions in Spain.

div.head: EGYPTIAN COTTON MILLS LTD.
div.p: LIQUIDATION DECIDED ON-
(Gazette* Special Service.)
London, Friday.
An extraordinary general meeting of the Egyptian Cotton Mills Limited was held yesterday at Winchester House, Old Broad Street, when the following resolution was considered and passed :—

"That it lias been proved to the satisfaction " of this Meeting that the Company cannot by " reason of its liabilities continue its business " and that it is advisable to wind up the same " and accordingly that the Company be wpund " up voluntarily, and that Messrs. Russell, " Kerr and Wyatt of Cairo, Alexandria, and " London be and they are hereby appointed " liquidators for the purposes of such wind- " ing up."
It was also decided that the liquidators should be assisted by an advisory committee composed of Maitre Carton de Wiart anil Mr. Cookson, the manager of the Anglo Egyptian Bank at Cairo.
WALKER AND MEIMARACHI
(Gaxotto'a Special Service.)
London, Thursday.

A private meeting of the I/ondon shareholders and the members of the London Board of Directors of Walker and Meiinarachi Limiter! was held to-day at the London offices of the Company. Maitre Carton de Wiart was present. No practical results were obtained. The English shareholders are unanimously supporting the London Board of Directors. An extraordinary meeting can he convened in July nexl.
LAND AND MORTGAGE CO- OF EGYPT
LIMITED-
The following is the report of tho directors, which is to be presented to-day at the twenty- seventh annual general meeting of the company, to be held in London :—

In presenting the twenty-seventh annual report of the company together with the balance sheet ami accounts for the year ended 31st March, 1907, the directors have again the pleasure of being able to state that tlie result of the year's operations justifies them not only in continuing the payment of a dividend for the whole year at the rate of 10 per cent,, but in adding 1 per cent, by way of bonus.

The shareholders were informed last year that to avoid the trouble and, expense incurred by the frequent re-issues of debentures to replace those paid oft' by drawings the directors had decided to create debenture stook, bearing 4 per cent, interest, of the total amount of £400,000 ; within which amount the company were empowered to issue and reissue debentures to rank pari passu in point of security, the resujt being that £106,700 4 per cent, debenture stock has been issued to date.

The directors have to lament the loss of their late colleague, Viscount Hampden, who died in November last In his place they have appointed Mr. Huri, their Manager in Egypt, who lias been a faithful sen-ant of the company for many years. The board were of opinion that ns nobody possessed so much knowledge of the affairs of the company as their manager, they cQuld not do better than reward his past services and secure them for the company by giving him a seat on the hoard.

The gross earnings for the past year amount to £45,502 8s. 3d. as against £45,900 0s. Gd. for the preceding year, and the net earnings to £17,477 0s. lod. as against £18,196 3s. lid. The gross earnings for the
Deducting total expenditure, including interest on debenture bonds and deben-

row.cell: The directors have placed £1,000 to reserve

div.p: staff's providont fund, leaving available a balance of £ 11^113 Os. id. Out of this they recommend thntn dividend of 5 per cent for the past six months be declared, which, with the 1 per cent, bonus, will absorb £9,000, leaving the sum of£2,113 0s. 4d. to he carried forward.

div.head: PORT SUDAN.
div.p: DEVELOPMENT OF TRADE. MR. KOHLER'S REPORT.
EXPORTS.

The exports from Port Sudan were at first 1 tampered by the unreadiness of the port, but gum, senna, etc. are now regularly shipped. Abyssinian coffee reaches the coast via Gain- bela and Khartoum, and ia gent from Port .Sudan to Aden, whence it is transhipped'to Europe and America. Goat-skins come from Kassala and are sent to Aden for America. Wheat comes from the Berber province, and is taken to Jeddah and the Yemen; and dhurra goes this way from Omdurman to Massowah. The principal items of export were as follows. The figures represent the value in £ sterling : Coffee, 438 ; .Skins, 1,309 ; Cattle, 25 ; Ghee, 804 ; Gum, 34,769 ; Senna, 105 ; Cotton, from the Atbara district, 240 ; Cotton seeds, 60 ; Sheep, 116. Tho above figures really only represent tho trade of Port Sudan from April 1 to October 31, os up to the former date the harbour was quite unprepared to receive ships. Also wash-outs on tho railway and quarantine (duo to the preaence of plague in Suez) did much to divert trade back to- the old Nile route. SHIPPING AT PORT SUDAN. From January 1 to October 31, 1906, 111 steamers, of 123,645 tons net, called at Port Sudan, and landed 744,280 packages. Of these 29 came direct from Europe, i e., 7 German, 3 Dutch and 19 British. The remainder came from Suez. Further, 134 coasting steamers brought 20,440 packages—mainly food stuffs from Suakin, whither the goods had been taken by ships which did not call at Port Sudan. In the same period 105 steamers, of 116,022 net tons, cleared, taking 18,836 packages, mostly gum. * Tho Suez.trade is at present practically a monopoly of the Khedivial Line. The Norddeutsoher Lloyd takes skins to Adjn for America, and they are making trial shipments of gum to Australia. It is stated that the Austrian Lloyd are about to start regular sailings to the port, and the Peninsular and Oriental are believed also to be considering tho matter. A new line is also reported to be in process of. formation. The other lines chiefly interested in the port at present are the Strtck Line and the Dale Line. t .The above figures are sufficient to show how considerable is the increase in the value of the goods passing through Port Sudan. It will now be suitable to consider the prospects of merchants desiring to establish a connection in the town. As already stated, the dangers which snr round the sea approach to Suakin cannot be said to exist here. Tho fairway ia clear and well-lighted and pilots ore available, if desired. Pilot dues will shortly be imposed, bat M yet there are no harbour or light Joes. The harbour is safe, but tho wharves and appliances for loading, dre,, are not yet ready, but before long the port will be aa well equipped as Alexandria.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: Sir W. Ghrstin and Mr. Webb are inspecting tlie new barrage at Esna.
Mr. E. B. Gould, ILB.M.'s Consul General for the City and Port of Alexandria, and Mrs. Gould uie in all probability proceeding to Europe at the end of June.
The French Government has bestowed the rosette of officer of the legion of Honour on Boghos Pasha Nubar.

The chairman of the Board of Directors of the Corporation of Western Egypt has had his portrait painted by Mr. Orchadson and it is hung in this year's academy. A critic ijays - The "W.C. Heaton-Armstrong, Esq. M.P." is a shadow, though still n very agreeable one, of the typical Orchardson portrait ; it looks more like u pastel drawing than a painting in oils.

A lianquot was given at the Semiramis Hotel, Cairo, by the members of the Cairo Bar to Hussein Rushdi Pasha on the occasion ot his appointment to tlie director-generalship of the Wakfs Administration.
Major Elgood, director of tho police school, will go on leave from June 22 to September 10.

Mr. A. Wild, manager of the Savoy.Hotel at Cairo, is hoping for Zurich 'to-qiorfow by tho Anstiap mail boat and will join his brothers at the National Hotel of that.fown, of which they arc the proprietors.

A marriage has been arranged between Mr. Gustave Runkewitx, the proprietor of the Savoy Hotel at Luxor and the Betu-Rivage Hotel at Ramieli, and Miss Emma Yunger, the niece of Mr. Bauer, proprietor of the Bristol Hotel, Cairo.
Mr. W. E. Kingsford baa left for France en route for England, where he well pass the summer at Barton-on-Sea, Hants.
We regret to announce the death which has occurred at Liverpool of Albert P. Moorhouse, General Manager of the Cunard Steamship Co., Limited.

div.head: THE RUINS OF PETRA.
A MYSTERIOUS CITY.
div.p: Ma'an, March 9.

It was an hour past noon ; since morning we had ridden up the gentle slope which declines from the broad, round-backed range of Edom on to the vast Arabian plateau, dim and illimitable behind us. We luul left the stretches of brown gravel strewn with black.flints, traversed the calcareous ridges, thinly clad with stunted, thorny bushes, and crossed the patches of snow in the hollows, which we ate and gave to our horses, for die sun was hot and we had the desert thirst on us. We came to n patch deeper than the rest, through which the horses floun- iered, slipping on the hidden stones. It proved to be the lust summit. "Behold Wady Moussa," said the most communicative of our escort of Kurdish cavalry. There was magic Ilk the. ridden change of scene. Before us rose a mountain muss of fantastic beauty, ravine and peak and precipice, overtopped by a weird peak towering in lonely grandeur. No need to tell ns that it was Mount Ilo'r, the lust resting place of Aaron, ami that hidden in the recess of those strange mountains lay Petra.

Down a narrow valley by a purling stream, the limestone clad with turf, whoso bright emerald was thickly studded with gay (lowers, we rode until our shadows grew long. As the light grew mellow we reached ii little plateau above the stream and were greeted by the barking of dogs, the cries of children, and the human sounds that haunt a village, even though it be hut the transitory home of nomads. Before sunset our tent was pitched, its white cone standing out sharply against the low black tents of the Bedouin who were to lie our neighbours for the night. They cleared away the stones from our camping ground, lent us tent-pegs, and helped our men to pitch the tent. The Sheikh sent us n carpet, a great boon for our equipment had been shamefully neglected by our civilised contractor. They supplied us with salt and delicious milk. Of course we had to take coflee with the Sheikh in his tent. The berries were of the semi- opaque variety which Yemen alone- produces. They were carefully doled oet from a bag into an iron ladle, roasted over the embers, pounded in a mortar, put into water and brought to boiling point. The process was lengthy, hut it resulted in a beverage totally differing from the black gruel, half coffee-grounds, known as Turkish coffee and mainly composed of burnt hurley. We were struck by the beauty of the children, slender and of delicate features. Our domestic arrangements excited interest. The bed linen was a subject of great wonder. But the people were very discreet, and retired the moment we showed a disposition to he left alone. For a time we heard conversation at the tent doors around ns—the quiet hum of u village. It was not easy to get rid of the notion that iliis was a permanent habitation. Yet on the morrow, perhaps, the "houses of hair" might vanish and not a human sight or sound break the solitude.

At sunrise we moved down the valley ; then mounted an acclivity to Kljy, the one village of the Wady Moussa oasis. The people are cultivators, settled Bedouin of pure race, ami here again wo were struck by tlie beauty of the type. The young girls were pictures of rustic comeliness, with dear, rosy complexions which not even profuse tattooing could hide. They were shy and dignified, and we rejoiced in the entire absence of the begging persecution to which travellers are subjected in Palestine. The valley narrowed into a ravine, and now we saw the first vestiges of antiquity —truncated pyramids cut dean away from 'the rock, dark doorways, carved friezes and pilasters with people grouped around them, for these chambers, unlike those of Petra, arc inhabited by the Arabs. The ravine ended in a sort of amphitheatre, and the stream made a sudden liend and disappeared through a narrow slit in the face of the precipice. We dismounted and plunged into it, for this was the Sik— strangest of approaches to a strange city. It is a diasm. a mere rent in the mountain, not more than twelve feet wide for much of its course, never more than thirty, with twists and turns innumerable. .'Sometimes the overhanging cliffs completely shut out the heavens anil made a red twilight. Then wotild cornea narrow, irregular ribbon of sky far above us. We seemed to he penetrating into the entrails of the earth rather than approaching the seat of a once opulent civilisation. We came to a wider opening and a grassy bank, on which we rested. Before us rose a huge shoulder, round which the water foamed into a narrow cleft. At length we turned it. Framed as in a

vignette by the jagged contour of the mouth of the chasm was an exquisite fairy-like thing of column and capital, frieze and niche and winged figures, not built, but hewn out of the nigged face of a precipice. It was of a delicate rosy line, and bathed in a flood of sunlight that shot across the gloom. Whatever it is, temple or tomb —the Arabs call it Pharaoh's Treasury,for they associate everything ancient with money,—it haunts the memory. We went down this broader ravine, making our way through the thickets of oleanders which lined the stream, the cliff's on cither hand honeycombed with rock-hewn cavities richly carted, differing each from each in bewildering variety. We came to the theatre, tier above tier cut out op the living rock, and we camped on a plateau of springy turf amid chimps of lilies. Westward loomed the rugged ruins of a mountain range dominated by the majestic rafts* of Mount Hor. Behind us rose a precipice whose ffice was carved into column, frieze, and cornice. Immediately above us was _» structure in an artificial recess with a terrace Hanked by cloister-like colonnades. A few yards beyond was what is called the Corinthian tomb, and f urther a stupendous cliff made into a pillared facade with projecting cornice. We were impressed most by the grandeur of the situation and the vast extent of the remains. In this confusion of mountains ravine after ravine is cut and carved into a labyrinth of ornate facades, some of them, as in the case of the great temple called the Deir, in almost inaccessible situations. There is a singular charm in the contrast between the elaborate work of a polished people and its ruggetf setting. Pilaster and colonnade and pediment are surmounted by jngged peaks and flanked by savage gorges.

The rain came on—March is a month too early for Petra,—and we shifted our tent into one of the rock-hewn cavities. Night fell, and by the light of the camp fire onr guards told us of bad Arabs yonder toyards Akaba who would kill n man for a beshlik—a trifle under sixpence. Sheikh Hamed, not to be outdone, told stories of leopards in the mountains who ate men, and gave a pantomimic illustration of the two blows from the paws of the beast, one on each side of the head. Though we wore not disturbed either by Arabs or leojiards, it was long before we slept, for the mystery of Petra had taken hold of us. Was it really a necropolis 1 Then why so vast for the small city, whose scanty remains at our feet took up scarce a square mile ? How much of the work wq# Nabathcan and how much Roman ? Were the cavities the dwellings of a primitive race adorned in a later age by a more polished people 1 The notices are so few and brief of this city without a story. They cease altogether in the sixth century. Then comes the great romance. For twelve long centuries the .very site, of these stupendous remains was unknown to civilised man, until that August day in 1812 when Burckhardt toiled through the Sik with a water-skin, while his Arab guide carried a kid, which was duly sacrificed at the tomb of Aaron. By this subterfuge only,could the intrepid explorer compass the discovery of the long lost city which his predecessor Seetzeu hud sought for in vain.

. There was no rain next morning, and we revelled in bur hath in the crystal rock pools of the stream,-while the sun wrought magic on I ho gorgeous colouring of the rocks. Sheikh Ilamerl and his men, who hud di.sappeared in the night, clattered down the ravine to greet iis. We had heard evil reports of the Petra Bedouin. We found them courteous and helpful. They are said to he rapacious ; wc only heard the word backsheesh once. It was uttered by a poor man who had led my horse. Ho was sternly repressed by the Sheikh, who was eon tent- with the very modest reward he received for his services. It is said that the good behaviour of the Bedouin was due to fear of the soldiers. We had two against at least a hundred armed men, who knew every inch of the country. I have heard of trouble with the Bedouin from people who boasted that they had threatened them with their repeating rides, and they were a strong party of men. I took my wife among them with perfect confidence, and we were unarmed. My confidence was justified. The Turkish Government obliged us to take an escort. Had we gone alone I am convinced we should have met with the same treatment, perhaps with greater sympathy. ("Manchester Guardian").

div.head: THE COTTON MARKET.
KHARSIKY AND CUNNTNOHAM'S WEEKLY REPORT
div.p: Liverpool, May 9th.
A moderate business has been done in Egyptian cotton- on thespot, quotations gener ally being 3/16 plb. dearer, except Fine Grown which is 1/2 plb. higher.
In futures a fair business has been done, prices fluctuating considerably, and the following are the latest quotations :—

American Futures. The Market this week has been active with frequent sharp fluctuations, but the tendency has been upwards and to-day's closing values, although 6 points below the highest rates touched, are 11 @ 14 points higher than those of last Thursday. The chief Causes of the advance) have been the continued excedingly unfavorable reports of the crop and the manipulation of the near positions. At the present moment weather conditions ure undoubtedly the predominating factor, and like all weather markets induce great sensitiveness and constantly fluctuating prices. One must acknowledge, that even allowing for exaggeration the conditions are sufficiently serious to cause anxiety.
